I've been working on better understanding limits (in my ongoing quest to understand how limits are preserved by certain representable functors!). My current understanding is that a limit of a diagram D:J→CD: J \to CD:J→C consists of two pieces of data (x,f)(x,f)(x,f), where:

  • xxx is an object of CCC
  • and f:C(−,x)≅Cone(−,D)f: C(-,x) \cong Cone(-,D)f:C(−,x)≅Cone(−,D) is a natural isomorphism

Here Cone(−,D):Cop→SetCone(-,D): C^{\textrm{op}} \to \mathsf{Set}Cone(−,D):Cop→Set sends an object c∈Cc \in Cc∈C to the set of cones over DDD with apex of ccc. And Cone(−,D)(f:c→d)Cone(-,D)(f: c \to d)Cone(−,D)(f:c→d) is a function f∗:Cone(d,D)→Cone(c,D)f^*:Cone(d,D) \to Cone(c,D)f∗:Cone(d,D)→Cone(c,D) which acts by precomposition "at the apex", so g↦g∘fg \mapsto g \circ fg↦g∘f for each "leg" ggg of a cone with apex ddd.

If we view xxx as a diagram with one object, I think that Cone(−,x)Cone(-,x)Cone(−,x) is very similar to the functor C(−,x)C(-,x)C(−,x). That is because a cone over a diagram with a single object xxx is just a morphism to xxx.

Inspired by this, I was wondering if it could be interesting to consider the concept of a "diagram limit". A diagram limit for a diagram D:J→CD: J \to CD:J→C of "shape" F:I→CF: I \to CF:I→C would consist of two pieces of data (F,f)(F,f)(F,f), where:

  • F:I→CF: I \to CF:I→C is a diagram in CCC
  • and f:Cone(−,F)≅Cone(−,D)f: Cone(-,F) \cong Cone(-,D)f:Cone(−,F)≅Cone(−,D) is a natural isomorphism

My hope is that even if a diagram D:J→CD: J \to CD:J→C doesn't have a limit (in the standard sense), it might have a diagram limit with respect to some F:I→CF: I \to CF:I→C where III is much "smaller" then JJJ. Intuitively, this might allow one to "compress" one's understanding of cones over D:J→CD: J \to CD:J→C to be in terms of cones over a smaller diagram F:I→CF: I \to CF:I→C.

Is this something that people do sometimes?

I'd also be interested in finding examples of diagrams D:J→CD: J \to CD:J→C that don't have a limit, but have a "diagram limit" (F:I→C,f)F: I \to C,f)F:I→C,f) where III is "smaller" than JJJ. (To determine if III is "smaller" than JJJ, we might ask if III has fewer morphisms than JJJ, for example).
You and I had begun discussing the preservation of limits by representable functors, and also the connection between this and the Yoneda lemma, but the discussion was dropped at some point.

In any case, let me encourage you to look more closely into how "Cone(−,x)Cone(-, x)Cone(−,x) is very similar to the functor C(−,x)C(-, x)C(−,x)". (Did you mean to write Cone(−,D)Cone(-, D)Cone(−,D)?) More precisely, let me encourage you to understand exactly how Cone(−,D)Cone(-, D)Cone(−,D) is defined in terms of categories, functors, and natural transformations. A cone is a certain natural transformation, but between which functors?
With regard to your idea of diagram limits, you might also be interested in the notion of "final functor", if you haven't bumped into this already.

Thanks for the suggestion! It will take me some time to think about this.

Although I can immediately clear this up: I did mean to write Cone(−,x)Cone(-,x)Cone(−,x), and not Cone(−,D)Cone(-,D)Cone(−,D). The idea is that Cone(−,x)Cone(-,x)Cone(−,x) is shorthand for Cone(−,F)Cone(-,F)Cone(−,F) where F:1→CF: 1 \to CF:1→C is the diagram that picks out the element x∈Cx \in Cx∈C. (Here 111 is a category with a single object and just the identity morphism).

I think I can start to clarify my understanding of how Cone(−,D)Cone(-,D)Cone(−,D) is defined in terms of categories, functors, and natural transformations. A cone over DDD with apex ccc is a natural transformation from a functor that is constant at ccc to the functor D:J→CD: J \to CD:J→C. We might call the constant functor Δc:J→C\Delta_c: J \to CΔc​:J→C.

So, we can consider the category of functors from JJJ to CCC and the natural transformations between them, [J,C][J,C][J,C]. The set of cones over DDD is I think then the set of morphisms from Δc:J→C\Delta_c: J \to CΔc​:J→C to D:J→CD: J \to CD:J→C. So, Cone(c,D)≅[J,C](Δc,D)Cone(c,D) \cong [J,C](\Delta_c, D)Cone(c,D)≅[J,C](Δc​,D).

We still have to consider how Cone(−,D)Cone(-,D)Cone(−,D) acts on morphisms. It is tempting at this point to guess that Cone(−,D)Cone(-,D)Cone(−,D) is [J,C](Δ−,D)[J,C](\Delta-, D)[J,C](Δ−,D), where Δ:C→[J,C]\Delta:C \to [J,C]Δ:C→[J,C] is some functor that sends an object ccc to the functor Δc:J→C\Delta_c: J \to CΔc​:J→C that is constant at ccc.

However, it will take me some work to properly figure this out!
In that case, Cone(−,x)≅C(−,x)Cone(-, x) \cong C(-, x)Cone(−,x)≅C(−,x) looks pretty tautological, if your shape category is the category 111 with exactly one object and morphism.
Your understanding of cones as natural transformations is correct!

To be honest, I hadn't thought about the role that the shape category plays here. I mostly just wanted the diagram corresponding to xxx to only have the object xxx and its identity morphism.
So if DDD has a limit, then [J,C](Δ−,D)≅C(−,lim⁡D)[J, C](\Delta-, D) \cong C(-, \lim D)[J,C](Δ−,D)≅C(−,limD).
We would say in that case that lim⁡D\lim DlimD "represents" the functor [J,C](Δ−,D)[J, C](\Delta -, D)[J,C](Δ−,D).
Yes, that all makes sense!

There's a good chance you know this already, but if every diagram DDD of shape JJJ in CCC has a limit, then the natural isomorphism

[J,C](Δx,D)≅C(x,lim⁡D)[J, C](\Delta x, D) \cong C(x, \lim D)[J,C](Δx,D)≅C(x,limD)

says that Δ:C→[J,C]\Delta: C \to [J, C]Δ:C→[J,C] has lim⁡:[J,C]→C\lim: [J, C] \to Clim:[J,C]→C for its right adjoint. But there's a nice little bit of categorical wisdom lurking there:

Namely, that even though we haven't quite defined how lim⁡\limlim is defined as a functor, the effect of lim⁡\limlim on morphisms is automatically determined by exploiting universal properties. More generally, the wisdom is that in order for a functor F:C→DF: C \to DF:C→D to have a right adjoint G:D→CG: D \to CG:D→C, it is sufficient that every functor D(F−,d)D(F-, d)D(F−,d) be representable (by an object of CCC). It's highly recommended that every student of category theory goes through this at one time in their life!

I think I have seen the natural isomorphism you describe above (in Leinster's book "Basic Category Theory"), although I did not understand it. I still don't understand why the isomorphism is natural in DDD, or exactly how lim⁡\limlim is a functor.

But I see that you indicate below that there is a way to figure out how lim⁡\limlim needs to act on morphisms using universal properties! That sounds pretty cool! The more general insight you share also sounds interesting. (Although I don't quite see how the pieces fit together though, just yet.)
Take your time with this! It's really worthwhile fitting all these pieces together. I don't remember how long it took me; I only remember that it was well worth the effort.

I will plan to chip away at this then! If I figure things out or get too stuck I'll hopefully post here about that.

(And thanks again for your comments in both this thread and the previous one on representable functors. Once I get a bit further with understanding preservation of limits, I am hopeful that I'll be able to post a bit again in that other thread too!)

Not sure if I should let you make that step on your own, but your question at the start (which I find quite interesting) essentially amounts to finding another diagram F:I→CF:I \to CF:I→C such that

[J,C](ΔJ−,D)≅[I,C](ΔI−,F)[J, C](\Delta^J-, D) \cong [I, C](\Delta^I-, F)[J,C](ΔJ−,D)≅[I,C](ΔI−,F)

This makes sense when JJJ and III are small and CCC is locally small (otherwise the functor categories involved might not be locally small). When DDD has a limit, you can pick F:1→CF: \mathbf{1} \to CF:1→C to be the constant functor at lim⁡D\lim DlimD. Otherwise, what does it mean for FFF and DDD to have the same cones?

There are some trivial cases. For instance when DDD is a diagram with one or more instances of a terminal object from CCC, you can remove them to get a diagram FFF, and cones over both diagrams will be the same thing (because a morphism from the tip of the cone to a terminal object adds no information EDIT: I was too quick en besogne, see James' answer below).

I am sure there are interesting cases, but I don't see any at the moment.
When D is itself a cone, it has the apex as a limit, but if it's a limiting cone you can also remove the apex and get a "diagram limit".
In fact whenever there's a limiting cone contained in D you can "safely" remove its apex; the above fact about terminal objects is a special case as 1\bold{1}1 by itself is a limiting cone.

There's kind of a trick to the sense of "contains" though. You can remove arrows into the apex, and you can remove arrows out of the apex that are part of the limiting cone, but arrows out of the apex that are not part of the limiting cone can't always be removed; a simple example is the diagram 1→1+1\bold{1} \to \bold{1} + \bold{1}1→1+1 (either one) where the 1\bold{1}1 can't be removed; with it the limit is 1\bold{1}1 and without it is 1+1\bold{1} + \bold{1}1+1.

However, you both seem to be indicating there is some additional subtlety here, so I suspect I am missing something!

Setting aside my confusion on this point for the moment, I am wondering if we can get interesting examples of "diagram limits" in a certain way. (The way I describe below might be what James Deikun mentioned above, but I am not sure).

The idea is that if you have a subdiagram in DDD that has a limit, then you can replace that subdiagram by (the object part of) its limit. Then it intuitively seems like the cones over the original diagram DDD and over the smaller resulting diagram FFF should be in bijection with one another.

Here is an illustration of the idea:
two diagrams with "equivalent" cones

The picture above shows two cones, each with apex xxx. I think there should be a bijection between the cones over the diagram with a,b,ca,b,ca,b,c on the left and the cones over the diagram with a×b,ca \times b,ca×b,c on the right. I haven't checked, but I am guessing this is a natural bijection so that the cone functors over these two diagrams are naturally isomorphic. That is, Cone(−,{a,b,c})≅Cone(−{a×b,c})Cone(-,\{a,b,c\}) \cong Cone(-\{a \times b, c\})Cone(−,{a,b,c})≅Cone(−{a×b,c}) where {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c} means the discrete diagram with objects aaa ,bbb, and ccc; and {a×b,c}\{a \times b, c\}{a×b,c} means the discrete diagram with objects a×ba \times ba×b and ccc.

The subtlety can arise only when the terminal object you remove has some morphisms going out of it in the diagram (which is not the case in your DLD_LDL​). The example James gave is below DLD_LDL​ is in green and DRD_RDR​ is in purple. A cone over DLD_LDL​ is not the same thing as a cone over DRD_RDR​. It is true that the morphism !:X→1{!}: X \to \mathbf{1}!:X→1 is uniquely determined (by terminality), but the morphism inl:1→1+1\mathsf{inl}:\mathbf{1} \to \mathbf{1}+\mathbf{1}inl:1→1+1 (which is the left coprejction) enforces that the morphism X→1+1X \to \mathbf{1}+\mathbf{1}X→1+1 must be inl∘!\mathsf{inl} \circ {!}inl∘! whereas it could be anything for the cone over DRD_RDR​.
